Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2019 Algorithmic Game Theory (AGT) Mentoring Workshop Co-Located with Economics and Computation (EC)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support students to attend the Algorithmic Game Theory (AGT) Mentoring Workshop and the 20th Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) Conference on Economics and Computation (EC), June 24 - 28, 2019, in Phoenix, AZ. The field of Algorithmic Game Theory is at the intersection of theoretical computer science and economics. This makes it most suitable to handle foundational issues posed by tremendous growth in economic and social systems on the Internet, and therefore the field has been thriving in the past few decades. Economics and Computation is the leading conference in this area, with the main aim of strengthening the field by bringing together both computer scientists and economists. The investigators are organizing a one-day AGT mentoring workshop to be co-located with EC.

The workshop will help to mentor and train students pursuing research careers in the field of AGT. Travel funds from NSF will facilitate participants' attendance at the mentoring workshop and EC, where they will learn about current research and interact with leaders in the field. The award will cover travel, lodging and registration fees for approximately 8 to 10 carefully selected students who otherwise would find it difficult to attend. The selection criteria for the travel award and the workshop program will aim to encourage participation by underrepresented minorities and women.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was used to fund the travel of seventeen students to attend a day-long mentoring workshop hosted by the PIs. The workshop was a part of Economics and Computation 2019, colocated with FCRC. Of the seventeen students, seven are from underrepresented demographics in STEM.

The workshop consisted of several organized activities, including a "Building your public image" talk, three sample job talks, and a panel discussion on the academic job market. Students also participated in small group lunches with faculty volunteers.

Intellectual Merit: The student participants will all be more in touch with the EC community as a result of the workshop, and have also acquired valuable (non-technical) skills necessary to succeed as part of a research community. Moreover, the students experienced top-notch job talks, which also contributed to their technical expertise.

Broader Impact: The workshop provided up-and-coming students with valuable experience. The students made numerous connections to each other, other students, and other faculty, and will now have a network when attending Economics and Computation in the future. Many of the students are from groups with are underrepresented in STEM. Moreover, many of the students are from universities which are not often represented at Economics and Computation, or from fields adjacent to computer science. Finally, some of the students are undergraduates or master's students, who are now better-informed about the potential of pursuing a PhD.
